The patient underwent left nephrectomy and renal transplant in Pakistan two months prior to 58 presentation where he was started on mycophenolate mofetil 365 mg BID and cyclosporine 75 mg BID 59 to prevent graft rejection.

FIGREF1.text: after transplant, the patient developed a painful ulcer on the lateral tongue and a 62 progressive, non-tender, white pseudo-membrane on the dorsal tongue. The transplant surgeon 63 diagnosed him with oral candidiasis and treated the patient with oral fluconazole as well as concomitant 64 dose reduction in mycophenolate. The patient's oral lesions continued to worsen despite the therapy. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic and air travel restrictions, the patient had to prematurely 66 terminate his stay in Pakistan and returned to the United States. Within a day of return, he noticed

FIGREF3.text: punch biopsy of skin at the ulcer edge was submitted for histopathology and tissue 79 culture. Within the dermis was a diffuse, mixed inflammatory infiltrate with scattered vascular 80 endothelial cells showing intranuclear inclusions, confirmed consistent with cytomegalovirus (CMV) on immunohistochemical staining. Blood CMV viral load was elevated to 401,000 IU/ml (ref ≤ 34 82 IU/ml). The lateral tongue ulcer was swab positive for herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) via polymerase 83 chain reaction (PCR). Other labs including CBC, CMP, UA were mostly unremarkable except for anemia 84 and high levels of serum ferritin. A contrasted CT abdomen and pelvis showed a peripherally enhancing 85 collection along the anterior abdominal wall within the superficial fat, along with surrounding satellite 86 pockets. 87 88 The patient was started on valganciclovir 900 mg BID and later transitioned to 89 intravenous ganciclovir 5 mg/kg every 12 hours. Exploratory surgery with washout and tissue cultures 90 grew Aspergillus flavus and multidrug resistant 91 Citrobacter freundii species. Isavuconazole and eravacycline were added for antimicrobial coverage.
